channel.title: Dbt on rmoff's random ramblings
channel.description: Recent content in Dbt on rmoff's random ramblings

item.title: Ten years late to the dbt party (DuckDB edition)
item.description:
Apparently, you can teach an old dog new tricks.

Last year I wrote a blog post about building a data processing pipeline using DuckDB to ingest weather sensor data from the UKâ€™s Environment Agency. The pipeline was based around a set of SQL scripts, and whilst it used important data engineering practices like data modelling, it sidestepped the elephant in the room for code-based pipelines: dbt.

item.title: Data Engineering in 2022: ELT tools
item.description: In my quest to bring myself up to date with where the data & analytics engineering world is at nowadays, Iâ€™m going to build on my exploration of the storage and access technologies and look at the tools we use for loading and transforming data.

item.title: Data Engineering in 2022: Wrangling the feedback data from Current 22 with dbt
item.description: I started my dbt journey by poking and pulling at the pre-built jaffle_shop demo running with DuckDB as its data store. Now I want to see if I can put it to use myself to wrangle the session feedback data that came in from Current 2022. Iâ€™ve analysed this already, but it struck me that a particular part of it would benefit from some tidying up - and be a good excuse to see what itâ€™s like using dbt to do so.

item.title: Data Engineering in 2022: Exploring dbt with DuckDB
item.description: Iâ€™ve been wanting to try out dbt for some time now, and a recent long-haul flight seemed like the obvious opportunity to do so. Except many of the tutorials with dbt that I found were based on using Cloud, and airplane WiFi is generally sucky or non-existant. Then I found the DuckDB-based demo of dbt, which seemed to fit the bill (ðŸ¦† geddit?!) perfectly, since DuckDB runs locally. In addition, DuckDB had appeared on my radar recently and I was keen to check it out.

item.title: Data Engineering in 2022: Architectures & Terminology
item.description: This is one of those you had to be there moments. If you come into the world of data and analytics engineering today, ELT is just what it is and is pretty much universally understood. But if youâ€™ve been around for â€¦waves handsâ€¦ longer than that, you might be confused by what people are calling ELT and ETL. Well, I was âœ‹.
